The addition of CG also mitigated heat-induced protein deterioration, such as changes in secondary structures and disulfide bonding.
population_specificity: In vitro study on myofibrillar proteins from surimi (fish-based) products.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only described as "introduced into MP").

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether encapsulating oregano essential oil (OEO) in gelatin/carrageenan (GE/CRG) microcapsules could improve its stability, slow-release properties, and antifungal efficacy against Botrytis cinerea.
results_summary: The study found that OEO-GE/CRG microcapsules achieved high encapsulation efficiency (87.79%), slow-release duration (over 80 hours), and strong antifungal activity (EC50 of 0.18 mg/mL), significantly prolonging the preservation of cherry tomatoes infected with B. cinerea.
population_specificity: Cherry tomatoes infected with Botrytis cinerea.
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on microcapsule properties and antifungal activity).
study_duration: Not specified (study measured slow-release duration up to 80 hours).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a κ-carrageenan/potato starch bio-hydrogel for removing methylene blue dye from water.
results_summary: The bio-hydrogel demonstrated excellent adsorption capacity (116.1 mg/g) for methylene blue, with high reusability (93% efficiency after five cycles), driven by electrostatic interactions and hydrogen bonding. The adsorption process was exothermic, spontaneous, and followed pseudo-second-order kinetics and the Langmuir isotherm model.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the wound healing potential of carrageenan in gel formulations for treating second-degree burn wounds.
results_summary: The 10% w/w carrageenan gel significantly enhanced wound healing in early stages, evidenced by collagen structure restoration and glycosaminoglycan configuration. The study suggests carrageenan gels improve healing efficiency in burn wounds.
population_specificity: Hairless female SKH-hr2 mice with burn-inflamed skin (n = 7 per treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of k-carrageenan on yield and the production of anti-diabetic agents in bitter melon (Jounpouri cultivar) farm crops.
results_summary: The study found that k-carrageenan (200, 400, and 600 mg l-1) increased fruit weight, dimensions, and yield over two consecutive years, though its specific impact on anti-diabetic agents was less highlighted compared to Ethrel and BRs.
population_specificity: Bitter melon (Jounpouri cultivar) farm crops.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of kappa-carrageenan (kC)-based hydrogels, combined with activated carbon (AC) or vanillin (V), for removing perfluorooctanoic acid (PFOA) from wastewater.
results_summary: The study found that kC hydrogels with AC or V significantly improved PFOA rejection and water permeability, with optimal performance at pH 4. The 3%kC-0.3%AC hydrogel achieved 86.9% PFOA rejection, while the 3%kC-3%V hydrogel achieved 85.7%, demonstrating effective and sustainable PFOA removal.
population_specificity: Synthetic and actual wastewater samples.
study_duration: Not specified (evaluated over three filtration cycles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of κ-carrageenan-based nano-in-micro hydrogels (CCMBs) for improving antibacterial activity and sustained release of curcumin against multi-drug resistant chronic wound pathogens.
results_summary: The study found that Cur-R-CCMBs demonstrated significant antibacterial activity against Staphylococcus aureus and Pseudomonas aeruginosa, along with high anti-oxidant, anti-inflammatory activity, and hemocompatibility. In vivo results showed a significant reduction in bacterial counts for both pathogens after 5 days.
population_specificity: Mice with chronic wound infections (in vivo model) and multi-drug resistant bacterial pathogens (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize quercetin pulmospheres using a combination of alginate-carrageenan polymers and study their characteristics as an inhalation delivery system for tuberculosis therapy.
results_summary: The study found that pulmospheres with alginate-carrageenan (1.8% total concentration) produced particles <3 µm in size, with high yield (83.89-86.30%), good entrapment efficiency (60.69-77.86%), and optimal drug loading (1.66-2.09%). The F2 formula (1:2 polymer ratio) was identified as the best formulation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of a kappa carrageenan-based hydrogel (KPB) for long-term removal of Oxytetracycline (OTC) from pharmaceutical wastewater.
results_summary: The kappa carrageenan-based hydrogel achieved up to 99% removal of OTC, with strong chemical adsorption indicated by high R² values (0.99 for KPB-3). The study found that chemisorption outperformed physical adsorption, and pH/concentration significantly influenced OTC removal.
population_specificity: Pharmaceutical wastewater (not human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: 0.1 g adsorbent dose at concentrations of 20-40 mg/L OTC.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the formation mechanism of HPP-induced emulsion gels containing κ-carrageenan and their ability to encapsulate and protect curcumin.
results_summary: The addition of κ-carrageenan reduced protein requirements for gel formation, decreased swelling rate, and improved gel strength and curcumin stability under specific pressure and holding time conditions. Optimal stability was achieved at a WPI-to-κ-CG ratio of 12:1 (1.0% κ-CG).
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
study_duration: Holding times of 10, 20, and 30 minutes under high pressure

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-amyloid efficacy and biocompatibility of liposomal nanoformulated iota carrageenan (nCG) compared to conventional carrageenan in degrading insulin amyloids.
results_summary: The study found that nCG demonstrated 17-20% higher degradation efficacy than conventional carrageenan and showed biocompatibility in vitro (V79 cells, human blood samples) and in vivo (zebrafish embryos and adults). Docking simulations suggested carrageenan's potential mechanism in inhibiting pancreatic insulin.
population_specificity: Zebrafish embryos, adult zebrafish, and V79 cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how varying concentrations of k-carrageenan (KCAR) affect the physical, mechanical, barrier, thermal, and microstructural properties of chicken gelatin (CGEL) composite films for biodegradable packaging.
results_summary: Increasing KCAR concentrations improved film lightness, opacity, water vapor permeability, tensile strength, and thermal stability, with the best results observed at 2% KCAR. The composite films showed superior properties compared to commercial cattle gelatin films, suggesting KCAR enhances biodegradable film performance.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on film properties).
study_duration: Not specified (laboratory-based study without intervention timeline).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of к-carrageenan-based hydrogel nanoparticles as a pH-controlled drug delivery system for targeted release of doxorubicin (DOX) to breast cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that the к-carrageenan hydrogel nanoparticles exhibited high encapsulation efficiency (96.1%) and controlled, pH-responsive release of DOX, with higher cytotoxicity toward MCF-7 breast cancer cells. The nanoparticles also demonstrated excellent antioxidant activity, blood compatibility, stability, and biodegradation.
population_specificity: L929 non-cancerous cells and MCF-7 breast cancer cells (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether carrageenan oligosaccharides (COs) could enhance the superchilling storage of crayfish by preserving muscle physicochemical features and protein integrity.
results_summary: COs treatment improved crayfish microstructure and protein stability during superchilling, up-regulating proteins involved in cell adhesion and cytoskeletal integrity. Proteomic analysis identified functional categories like post-translational modification and signal transduction as key mechanisms of COs' protective effects.
population_specificity: Crayfish (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-edematous effects of three second-generation histamine H1-receptor blockers using a λ-carrageenan-induced footpad edema model in rats.
results_summary: Epinastine hydrochloride and levocetirizine hydrochloride significantly suppressed edema in a dose-dependent manner, while cetirizine hydrochloride showed a slight effect. Dextrocetirizine did not prevent edema growth.
population_specificity: Rats (animal model)
study_duration: Edema evaluated at 0.5 and 3 hours post-carrageenan injection

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how ultrasound combined with pre- or post-addition of κ-carrageenan affects the gelling properties, structural characteristics, and rheological behavior of myofibrillar proteins under low-salt conditions.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasound combined with pre-addition of κ-carrageenan significantly improved gel strength, water holding capacity, and rheological behavior of myofibrillar protein gels, while post-addition showed limited effectiveness. Microstructural analysis confirmed denser gel formation with pre-addition.
population_specificity: Myofibrillar proteins under low-salt conditions (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of κ-carrageenan (κ-CAR) and other additives on the gel properties and protein structures of minced pork to improve its quality.
results_summary: The study found that κ-CAR combined with wheat gluten (WG) resulted in the densest and most stable gel network structure in minced pork, improving hardness, chewiness, and water retention. The treatment also altered protein secondary structures, reducing α-helix content from 27% to 7.8%.
population_specificity: Minced pork (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the anti-inflammatory effects of grape pomace polyphenols in a carrageenan-induced paw edema model in mice.
results_summary: Carrageenan was used to induce paw edema and inflammation in mice, and grape pomace polyphenols significantly reduced inflammation markers (COX-2, MPO, IL-1β, IL-6) and lipid peroxidation in a dose-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Mice (animal model)
effective_dosage: Subplantar injection of carrageenan (dose not specified); GP polyphenols administered intraperitoneally at 10, 20, and 40 mg/kg.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether low-intensity pulsed ultrasound (LIPUS) could suppress macrophage polarity and infrapatellar fat pad (IFP) fibrosis in a carrageenan-induced knee osteoarthritis (KOA) rat model.
results_summary: The study found that LIPUS irradiation reduced M1 macrophage markers and increased M2 macrophage markers, decreased TGF-β and type 1 collagen expression, and reduced fibrosis in the IFP of carrageenan-induced KOA rats.
population_specificity: Wistar rats (eight weeks old) with carrageenan-induced knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (carrageenan injection used to induce KOA).
study_duration: Two weeks of LIPUS irradiation following carrageenan injection.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a double-network hydrogel containing κ-carrageenan in promoting wound healing for second-degree burns in rats.
results_summary: The hydrogel formulations, especially HLC (hydrogel + lactoferrin + Cramoll), showed superior wound contraction, reduced inflammation, tissue necrosis, and fibrosis, and promoted re-epithelialization compared to controls. The hydrogels maintained stability without significant pH or microbiological changes over 90 days.
population_specificity: Wistar rats with induced second-degree burns.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the dispersion of cellulose nanocrystals (CNCs) in carrageenan biocomposites using mechanochemical treatment in a deep eutectic solvent (DES) to enhance material properties.
results_summary: The study found that DES treatment improved CNC dispersion, increasing zeta potential by 43.2%, enhancing crystallinity from 76% to 81%, and boosting tensile and capsule loop strength by 20.7% and 19.4%, respectively. Surface roughness of the biocomposite was reduced by 21.8%.
population_specificity: Not applicable (material science study, no human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of carrageenan-based biopolymer membranes for removing methylene blue (MB) from water in filtration systems.
results_summary: The study found that lambda carrageenan/calcium alginate (λ-Car/CaAlg) membranes achieved 100% dye rejection and high flux (11.67 L m-2 h-1), outperforming other formulations. The membranes also demonstrated excellent recyclability over nine cycles.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study using synthetic water samples).
study_duration: Not applicable (performance tested over nine cycles).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of κ-Carrageenan on frozen-thawed porcine semen quality, focusing on sperm kinematics, viability, and oxidative stress protection.
results_summary: The study found that 0.2 mg/mL κ-Carrageenan improved sperm motility, viability, mitochondrial membrane potential, and acrosome integrity while reducing lipid peroxidation, indicating enhanced cryopreservation outcomes.
population_specificity: Frozen-thawed porcine spermatozoa
effective_dosage: 0.2, 0.4, 0.6, and 0.8 mg/mL κ-Carrageenan in freezing extender
study_duration: Immediate assessment post-thawing and after 120 minutes of incubation

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of κ-carrageenan (KC) concentration and crosslinking on the stability, mechanical properties, and probiotic encapsulation efficacy of emulsion gels.
results_summary: The study found that KC, when combined with citric acid and K+, formed stable double-network emulsion gels with improved probiotic survival rates under high temperatures, freezing, and gastrointestinal conditions. The optimal formulation (0.8 wt% KC, 0.09 wt% citric acid, and K+) demonstrated the lowest swelling ratio (9.41%) and highest probiotic protection.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study involving emulsion gels and probiotics).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the multifaceted properties of carrageenan (CRG) and its potential applications in biomedical fields such as drug delivery, wound healing, and tissue regeneration.
results_summary: The study highlights CRG's diverse properties, including antiviral, antibacterial, immunomodulatory, and antioxidant effects, and its successful use in developing scaffolds and drug delivery systems for tissue repair and disease intervention.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of existing research)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to maximize carrageenan recovery from Sarcopeltis skottsbergii and evaluate its chemical, structural, and biological properties for potential food applications.
results_summary: The carrageenan showed promising rheological properties for food use, with high molecular weight (500 kDa) and cell viability above 70%. However, hydrogels synthesized from it had cell viability below 50%, and a low inflammatory response was observed at 0.025% concentration.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or lab-based study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether carrageenan use affected anal HPV16 and HPV18 viral loads in gbMSM, following its lack of protective effect in reducing HPV acquisition or clearance.
results_summary: Carrageenan use did not significantly alter HPV16 or HPV18 viral loads compared to placebo, with no statistically meaningful differences observed. The results were consistent regardless of HIV status.
population_specificity: Gay, bisexual, and other men who have sex with men (gbMSM), including 54 HIV-positive participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects of a novel diselenide compound (DD) on carrageenan-induced inflammation in murine models and human neutrophils.
results_summary: DD significantly reduced carrageenan-induced inflammation by decreasing neutrophil migration, oxidative burst, and inflammatory markers (MPO activity, lipid peroxidation, cytokines) in both in vitro and in vivo models. It also showed no toxicity at tested doses.
population_specificity: Murine models (mice) and human neutrophils in vitro.
effective_dosage: 25, 50, and 75 mg/kg (intraperitoneal) in mice; 3.7–25 µM in vitro.
study_duration: Up to 48 hours in vitro; 15 days for toxicity assessment in mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the mechanical properties, fatigue resistance, and usability of conductive hydrogels by developing a borax-crosslinked polyvinyl alcohol/k-carrageenan hydrogel (BPKKOH) with KOH treatment.
results_summary: The KOH treatment significantly enhanced hydrogen bonding, tensile and compressive strengths, fatigue resistance, and shape recovery after water loss. The BPKKOH hydrogel demonstrated effective monitoring of finger bending and potential applications in smart wearables and information transmission.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how ultrasound treatment combined with κ-carrageenan (KC) affects the gel properties, structural characteristics, and microstructure of myofibrillar protein (MP) gel.
results_summary: Adding KC alone improved gel strength and water holding capacity (WHC) of MP gels. Synergizing KC with 20 minutes of ultrasound treatment further increased gel strength by 56.67% and WHC by 76.19%, attributed to protein rearrangement and stronger binding, though excessive ultrasound treatment (40-50 minutes) weakened the gel structure.
population_specificity: In vitro study (myofibrillar protein gels)
study_duration: Ultrasound treatment durations of 20, 40, and 50 minutes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if degrading κ-carrageenan (KC) into low molecular weight derivatives (DCPs) could enhance its antibacterial activity while retaining its structural properties.
results_summary: The study found that DCPs exhibited strong antibacterial activity against multiple bacterial strains, with MIC values ranging from 4.5 to 5.25 mg/mL. The antibacterial mechanism involved binding to bacterial membrane proteins and altering permeability.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on bacterial strains).
effective_dosage: MIC values of 5.25, 4.5, 5.25, and 4.5 mg/mL for different bacterial strains.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a carrageenan-based biosorbent material for treating industrial wastewater contaminated with cationic dyes like methylene blue.
results_summary: The study found that the carrageenan-grafted biosorbent demonstrated high adsorption capacity (802.6 mg/g) for methylene blue, attributed to its functional groups, and fitted well with established kinetic and isotherm models. The material showed improved hydrophilicity and surface morphology, enhancing its sorption potential.
population_specificity: Industrial wastewater treatment applications (no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (material was grafted in layers with SFP polymer and crosslinked with BTCA).
study_duration: Adsorption tests were conducted over 120 minutes under specific conditions (pH = 4, T = 22°C).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a biodegradable, eco-friendly, and antimicrobial food packaging film using Carrageenan and silver nanoparticles synthesized via a green method.
results_summary: The Ag/Carr nanocomposite film demonstrated improved UV barrier, mechanical, and antimicrobial properties, effectively increasing the shelf life of packed cottage cheese and strawberries. The film was biodegradable within four weeks.
population_specificity: Food packaging applications (tested on cottage cheese and strawberries).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether incorporating hydrochar-derived activated carbon into carrageenan hydrogel beads improves their adsorption capacity and mechanical properties for wastewater treatment.
results_summary: Increasing activated carbon content in carrageenan hydrogel beads significantly enhanced gel content and swelling ratio, with optimal adsorption capacities for methylene blue ranging from 475.48 to 635.93 mg/g depending on the carrageenan/activated carbon ratio. The adsorption process was spontaneous and exothermic, driven by mechanisms like electrostatic attraction and hydrogen bonding.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on hydrogel beads).
effective_dosage: Carrageenan to activated carbon ratios of 1:0 (CAR), 2:1 (CAC2), 4:1 (CAC4), and 10:1 (CAC10).
study_duration: Not specified (batch adsorption tests under varying conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the anti-inflammatory activity of exopolysaccharide (EPSSM) using carrageenan-induced paw edema in rats.
results_summary: EPSSM demonstrated significant anti-inflammatory effects in the carrageenan-induced paw edema model, reducing oxidative stress markers (catalase, superoxide dismutase, glutathione) and inflammatory mediators (nitric oxide, lipid peroxidation, reactive oxygen species, cyclooxygenase-2, interleukin-6). The antioxidant activity of EPSSM also increased with concentration, peaking at 94.13% at 100 µg/mL.
population_specificity: Rats with carrageenan-induced paw edema.
study_duration: Effects were measured at 2, 3, and 4-hour intervals post-administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of ultrasound treatment on the stability and encapsulation efficiency of carrageenan/sodium alginate-stabilized zein nanoparticles loaded with daidzein.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment improved encapsulation efficiency (90.36%), reduced particle size, enhanced stability and solubility, and maintained nanoparticle structure. It also increased antioxidant activity and enabled slow release of daidzein in the gastrointestinal tract.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)
effective_dosage: Ultrasound treatment at 320 W for 15 min

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biocompatibility and suitability of methacrylate-κ-carrageenan (MA-κ-CA) mixed with bioactive silica nanoparticles (BSNPs) for bone tissue engineering using 3D printing.
results_summary: The study found that MA-κ-CA-BSNP scaffolds exhibited high cell viability, no cytotoxicity, enhanced osteogenic differentiation, and no inflammation in vivo, demonstrating their potential for bone tissue engineering.
population_specificity: MC3T3-E1 pre-osteoblast cells (in vitro) and Wistar rats (in vivo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and effectiveness of Callergin, a nasal spray containing iota-carrageenan, in alleviating symptoms of grass pollen-induced allergic rhinitis.
results_summary: The study found that Callergin slightly reduced nasal allergy symptoms compared to no treatment, with a statistically significant reduction in TNSS at 3 hours post-treatment. Rhinorrhea and congestion showed the most improvement, and the treatment was safe and well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Adults with grass pollen-induced allergic rhinitis.
study_duration: Prophylactic administration followed by a 3-hour allergen exposure, with treatment blocks separated by 7-day washout periods.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of intramuscular ozone therapy on nociception, inflammation, and tissue damage caused by carrageenan injection in rat masseter muscles.
results_summary: Carrageenan injection caused mechanical allodynia and inflammation, which were reduced by ibuprofen but not ozone therapy. Ozone therapy did not protect against carrageenan-induced tissue damage but showed increased collagen fibers and regenerating myofibers.
population_specificity: Adult male rats
effective_dosage: Not specified for carrageenan (ozone: 20 µg/mL, 5% ozone + 95% oxygen, administered three times in a week)
study_duration: One or eight days post-carrageenan injection

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immunomodulatory properties of carrageenan and other polysaccharides from various algal species, focusing on their effects on inflammation, wound healing, and other bioactivities.
results_summary: Carrageenan fractions from C. crispus and S. gaudichaudii showed anti-inflammatory effects, improved wound healing, and enhanced phagocytosis, while some fractions also exhibited anti-coagulation activity. Certain fractions stimulated cell proliferation, while others inhibited it, depending on extraction conditions.
population_specificity: RAW264.7 macrophages (in vitro study)
study_duration: Up to 48 hours for proliferation assays, 24 hours for NO secretion and cytokine expression

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial efficacy and stability of carrageenan-based hydrogels loaded with bacteriophages for wound dressing applications.
results_summary: The carrageenan hydrogel (carr-vB_Eco2571-YU1) demonstrated effective bacteriolytic activity against E. coli without inducing phage resistance, maintained stability under various conditions, and showed hemocompatibility. The hydrogel's compressive strength decreased with added plasticizer, but elasticity improved.
population_specificity: Pathogenic Escherichia coli (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how kappa-carrageenan (k-carr) interacts with buckwheat protein (BWPE) to enhance gel structure and tailor textural properties for food applications.
results_summary: The study found that composited gels with 1% w/w BWPE and 1% w/w k-carr showed significantly higher hardness and storage modulus compared to k-carr alone. K-carr reinforced the protein gel network, altered protein secondary structure, and increased β-sheet content, leading to a more organized gel structure.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the development and antimicrobial efficacy of nanocomposites combining k-carrageenan and linseed mucilage for sustained release of herbal constituents in bovine mastitis treatment.
results_summary: The nanocomposites exhibited thermoreversible properties, gradual release of phenolic compounds (80% within 72 h), and inhibited MRSA growth for 8 h, with no toxicity observed in MAC-T cells.
population_specificity: Bovine mastitis treatment (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 1.25 mg of macela extract/g of gel (various polymer ratios: 8:2, 7:3, 5:5 w/w).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the heat stability of milk proteins in the presence of varying levels of κ-carrageenan under combined heat treatment and shear conditions.
results_summary: Shear forces led to reduced non-sedimentable proteins, increased particle size, and higher apparent viscosity, particularly at higher κ-carrageenan concentrations and elevated temperatures, indicating protein aggregation due to destabilized micelles and loosely bound caseins within the κ-carrageenan network.
population_specificity: Milk protein dispersions with added cocoa powder and sucrose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of novel cross-linked tosyl-carrageenan/alginate (Ts-Car/Alg) beads in removing Pb2+ ions from aqueous solutions.
results_summary: The Ts-Car/Alg beads demonstrated strong adsorption capacity for Pb2+ ions (74 mg/g) at pH 5.3 after 120 minutes, with successful reusability over two cycles. The Freundlich model best fit the adsorption data, and kinetics followed a pseudo-second-order model.
population_specificity: Aqueous solutions contaminated with Pb2+ ions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop inhalable microspheres using carrageenan and other polymers for targeted drug delivery in tuberculosis treatment.
results_summary: The study found that carrageenan-based microspheres had smooth surfaces, spherical shapes, and sizes below 5 μm, with good drug loading and entrapment efficiency (62.44–85.30%). Drug release followed Fickian diffusion, indicating effective lung-targeted delivery.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how different forms of κ-carrageenan (dry powder or water suspension) and ionic strength affect the physicochemical and gelling properties of myofibrillar protein (MP).
results_summary: Incorporating κ-carrageenan (either form) improved MP's gelling properties, resulting in a more compact and homogenous gel network. The water suspension form (CW) showed higher gel strength, water holding capacity, and intermolecular interactions compared to the dry powder form (CP), especially at 0.3 M NaCl. Higher NaCl concentration (0.6 M) further enhanced gelling properties.
population_specificity: Myofibrillar protein (MP) in a laboratory setting (no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (tested at 0.3 M and 0.6 M NaCl concentrations).
study_duration: Not specified (focused on heating treatment effects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the anti-inflammatory mechanism of Paridis rhizoma extract (PRE) in rat models of acute inflammation induced by carrageenan.
results_summary: PRE reduced interstitial edema and structural damage in carrageenan-induced paw edema in rats and inhibited inflammatory responses by decreasing inflammatory factors and ROS production while increasing antioxidant expression. PRE also suppressed the NF-kB pathway.
population_specificity: Rats (in vivo) and RAW264.7 cells (in vitro)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a biocompatible polysaccharide film using κ-carrageenan gum (CG) and xanthan gum (XG) for vaginal application, specifically to deliver a sesame seed oil nanoemulsion (SONE) with anti-Trichomonas vaginalis activity.
results_summary: The study found that a blend of XG and CG (2%, ratio 1:3) produced a promising film (XCF) with suitable mechanical and mucoadhesive properties for vaginal use. The SONE-loaded film (SONE-XCF) demonstrated high absorption capacity, long disintegration time (>8h), and safety in hemolysis and chorioallantoic membrane tests.
population_specificity: Not explicitly stated, but implied to be relevant for women with trichomoniasis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the molecular basis of Kappa-carrageenan (KCG)-induced platelet activation and identify the receptor and signaling pathways involved.
results_summary: KCG induces platelet aggregation via the C-type lectin-like receptor-2 (CLEC-2), activating tyrosine kinase-dependent pathways, and this effect was abolished in CLEC-2-deficient mice. KCG also triggered thrombosis and thrombocytopenia, which were significantly inhibited in CLEC-2-deficient mice.
population_specificity: Platelets from platelet receptor-deficient mice and recombinant proteins were studied.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effect of ultrasound treatment and κ-carrageenan (KC) addition on the gelling properties and rheological behaviors of myofibrillar protein (MP).
results_summary: KC incorporation improved gel strength and water-holding capacity (WHC) of MP gels, with further enhancement from 20-minute ultrasound treatment. Longer ultrasound treatment times (30-50 min) reduced gel quality, leading to loose and disordered structures.
population_specificity: Myofibrillar protein (MP) gels (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (KC incorporation level not detailed).
study_duration: Ultrasound treatment times ranged from 20 to 50 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Kappa carrageenan (K-carr) as a coating for targeted drug delivery of paclitaxel (PTX) to breast cancer cells.
results_summary: The study found that K-carr-coated nanoparticles demonstrated high encapsulation efficiency (84.58%) and loading capacity (13.2%) for PTX, with strong cytotoxicity (IC50 of 12 μg/mL) and induction of apoptosis (40.25%) in MCF-7 cells. The coating facilitated controlled drug release and enhanced targeted chemotherapy efficacy.
population_specificity: MCF-7 breast cancer cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study focused on nanoparticle formulation rather than direct carrageenan dosage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate a novel biomass-based aerogel (PPEKC) containing κ-carrageenan for efficient dye wastewater treatment.
results_summary: The PPEKC aerogel demonstrated high adsorption capacities for both anionic (2016.7 mg g-1 for congo red) and cationic (1176.6 mg g-1 for methylene blue) dyes, with ultra-fast adsorption rates, pH-tunable selectivity, and favorable reusability and antibacterial activity.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on dye adsorption).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the biomedical and industrial applications of Carrageenan, including its underlying mechanisms and the synergistic effects of nanotechnology.
results_summary: The study found that Carrageenan exhibits significant biological activities such as antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, and antitumor effects, influenced by factors like sulfation pattern and molecular weight. Nanotechnology-enhanced Carrageenan bio-composites showed improved stability, biodegradability, and biocompatibility, making them suitable for drug delivery, wound-healing, and tissue engineering.
population_specificity: Not specified (general biomedical and industrial applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the safety and effects of food-grade carrageenan on patients with quiescent ulcerative colitis (UC) compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences in clinical or biochemical markers between carrageenan and placebo periods. Gastrointestinal symptoms were actually higher during the placebo period, with some symptoms significantly worse than during carrageenan use.
population_specificity: Patients (n = 7) with quiescent ulcerative colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily prophylactic carrageenan nasal spray reduces upper respiratory tract infection (URTI) symptoms and rhinovirus levels compared to saline placebo or no treatment.
results_summary: Regular carrageenan use showed consistent but nonsignificant reductions in URTI symptoms versus placebo. Saline placebo had mixed effects on cold symptoms compared to no treatment, and low compliance suggests carrageenan may be more suitable for populations with specific URTI avoidance needs.
population_specificity: 102 adults (plus 42 controls)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the characteristics of pea protein isolate and κ-carrageenan complexes in stabilizing curcumin-loaded emulsions and their potential to enhance emulsion stability and curcumin chemical stability.
results_summary: The study found that pea protein isolate and κ-carrageenan complexes improved emulsion stability by acting as a steric barrier, increasing net negative charge and adsorbed protein content. The chemical stability of curcumin was significantly enhanced after heating treatment, and synergistic antioxidant activity between grape seed oil and curcumin was observed.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether enzymatically digested κ-carrageenan oligosaccharides (KOS) have therapeutic or preventive effects in an Alzheimer's disease (AD) model using APP/PS1 transgenic mice.
results_summary: KOS alleviated clinical symptoms in AD mice, reduced inflammatory factors and inflammation-related proteins in brain tissue, and inhibited microglial overactivation, demonstrating neuroprotective effects.
population_specificity: APP/PS1 transgenic mice (Alzheimer's disease model)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop mucoadhesive biopolymer-based composite sponges for buccal delivery of THC to enhance its chemopreventive and anticancer effects against oral precancerous lesions.
results_summary: THC-nanocrystals (THC-NC) showed enhanced anticancer activity against SCC-4 cells (IC50: 80 µg/mL) and THC-NC-loaded sponges (THC-NC-S) demonstrated sustained drug release, significant regression in dysplasia, and reduced cyclin D1 levels in DMBA-induced hamster OPL.
population_specificity: Human tongue squamous carcinoma cell line (SCC-4) and DMBA-induced hamster oral precancerous lesions.
effective_dosage: THC-NC concentration of 80 µg/mL (IC50) in vitro; in vivo dosage not specified.
study_duration: 25 days of treatment in the hamster model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-thrombotic effect of Nemopilema nomurai jellyfish venom (NnV) using a κ-carrageenan-induced rat tail thrombus model.
results_summary: NnV demonstrated anti-thrombotic activity in a dose-dependent manner, reducing thrombus formation and length in κ-carrageenan-induced SD rats. The study also found that NnV inhibited PDGF-BB-stimulated migration and proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells by modulating MMP-2, ERK, and Akt pathways.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biophysical properties of different carrageenan molecules and their effects on human umbilical cord-derived mesenchymal stromal cells to identify an optimal macromolecular crowding agent for tissue engineering.
results_summary: Lambda medium viscosity carrageenan at 10 and 50 μg/ml significantly increased extracellular matrix deposition (collagen types I, III, IV, fibronectin, and laminin) without affecting cell morphology, viability, metabolic activity, proliferation, or surface marker expression. Two iota carrageenans were excluded due to poor solubility.
population_specificity: Human umbilical cord-derived mesenchymal stromal cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of carrageenan in a zinc/carrageenan gel as an on-demand multipurpose prevention technology for HIV-1 and HSV-2 prevention.
results_summary: The abstract mentions a zinc/carrageenan gel as an on-demand product for HIV-1/HSV-2 prevention, but no specific efficacy or safety results for carrageenan are provided.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of increasing sea buckthorn oil concentrations on the structural, physicochemical, release, and antioxidant properties of sodium casein and gelatin films.
results_summary: Sodium casein films showed lower compactness, crystallinity, transparency, surface hydrophobicity, oxygen barrier performance, strength, and antiradical activity compared to gelatin films. Sea buckthorn oil improved water vapor barrier properties in both films but reduced tensile strength at higher concentrations while increasing antiradical activity.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on film properties)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of varying carrageenan levels (2.4%, 2.65%, and 2.9%) on peanut pasta quality, including texture, moisture content, and cooking loss.
results_summary: Higher carrageenan levels reduced cooking loss in peanut pasta, improving dough viscosity and pasta firmness. The study found carrageenan effective in enhancing pasta quality when combined with peanut flour.
population_specificity: Not specified (general food application study).
study_duration: Not specified (single preparation and testing phase).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the remineralization effects of a toothpaste containing fluoride, casein phosphopeptide amorphous calcium phosphate (CPP-ACP), and sodium trimetaphosphate (TMP) on initial caries lesions.
results_summary: The study found that the combined use of fluoride, CPP-ACP, and TMP in toothpaste significantly enhanced remineralization of enamel surface and subsurface lesions, with higher calcium and phosphorus concentrations compared to conventional fluoride toothpaste. The 1100F-CPP-ACP-TMP treatment showed the greatest remineralization, outperforming other formulations.
population_specificity: 10 volunteers using palatal appliances with bovine enamel specimens.
effective_dosage: 1100 ppm fluoride + 10% CPP-ACP + 3% TMP in toothpaste.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop printable protein-based medium internal phase emulsions (MIPEs) with low oil fraction using casein and tamarind seed polysaccharide (TSP) to improve rheological properties for 3D printing.
results_summary: The study found that post-acid-treated MIPEs co-stabilized with casein and TSP showed significant improvements in G' and viscosity, achieving self-supporting properties suitable for 3D printing. Higher TSP concentrations further enhanced these rheological properties.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to optimize a kinase inhibitor targeting fungal Yck2 (a casein kinase 1 family member) to develop novel antifungal agents against Candida albicans.
results_summary: The study identified two 6-cyano derivatives with improved pharmacological properties that retained bioactivity against fungal Yck2 while showing selectivity over human CK1α. These analogs demonstrated efficacy against echinocandin-resistant C. albicans in mice and enhanced the effects of non-curative echinocandin treatment.
population_specificity: Mice infected with Candida albicans (fungal infection model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how high hydrostatic pressure (HHP) treatment affects the structural, physicochemical, and functional properties of buffalo milk casein.
results_summary: HHP altered the protein's spatial structure, improved dispersion and foaming properties, and enhanced antioxidant activity and antibacterial effects against E. coli, but reduced water-holding capacity, emulsion stability, and antibacterial activity against S. aureus.
population_specificity: Buffalo milk casein (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (pressure levels varied but exact dosages not mentioned).
